body_content.explanation: a device for measuring and showing time, usually found in or on a building and not worn by a person:
examples: We have an antique clock on our mantelpiece.
The town-hall clock says (= shows that the time is) nine o'clock.
I think the kitchen clock is fast/slow (= is showing a later/earlier time than it should).
The clock began to strike twelve.
She set her clock (= put it to the right time) by the time signal on the radio.

body_content.explanation: to change the time on your clocks to an hour earlier, at an officially chosen time of year:
examples: Don't forget to turn the clocks back tonight.

body_content.explanation: to change the time on your clocks to an hour later, at an officially chosen time of year:
examples: We turn the clocks forward today, so our children will be short of sleep.

body_content.explanation: a speedometer (= a device that measures speed):
examples: I was only doing 30 mph on the clock.

body_content.explanation: a milometer (= a device for recording distance travelled):
examples: My car's only got 10,000 miles on the clock.

body_content.explanation: to take a particular time exactly to do or complete something:
examples: He clocked ten seconds in the 100 metres (= he ran it in ten seconds).

body_content.explanation: to show or reach a particular speed or distance on a measuring device:
examples: The police clocked him doing 80 mph in a 50 mph area.
Jim's car has clocked (up) (= travelled) 40,000 miles in less than two years.

body_content.explanation: to hit someone, especially on the head or face:
examples: Then the other guy turned round and clocked him one (= hit him).
